text: Wedding GUESTS in hoop skirts and morning suits roam abou
Ten BRIDESMAIDS clad in fuchsia primp and gossip. A FLOWE GIRL frolics amidst balloons.

The room of the consummate beauty pageant contestant. Ina white hoop skirt stands belle of the ball DELILAH MACINTO early 20s. Tending to the bride are: mother MIRABELLE, a domineering matriarch; bridesmaid CHARLENE, Delilah's older, heavier sister; and bridesmaid MARNEY, fetching and shallow.
I can't believe my weddin' day is finally here. In an hour, I'll be married to the man o' my dreams. Somebody pinch me. Charlene pinches her, hard.
Ow! I meant, figuratively.
I pinched your figure, didn't I?
(pirouettes) How do I look?
Like you crap diamonds.
Marney. I don't appreciate such language in my house.
Sorry, Mrs. M. It just sort of... (eyes Delilah in mirror) slid out. Delilah holds... then bursts into giggles.
(stamps her shoe) Enough of that! This is your wedding day for heaven's sake. Not some tawdry night in a cheap motel. Charlene, doesn't your sister look beautiful?
(admitting defeat) Yes, Momma. She crouches to adjust Delilah's skirt.
I feel like a whale in this thing, just waiting to be harpooned.
Tell me about it.
(pats Marney's arm) You're not a whale, Honey. She brushes past Charlene, who reddens.
It's only for a few hours. Then y'all can get naked, hop on an usher, and jump in the pool.
They will do no such thing.
I'm just teasin', Momma. Try and relax. You're makin' me nervous.
A bride is supposed to be nervous on her wedding day.
Like it's a law or something?
It is a law. Your family comes bearing gifts. Don't you want to make a good impression on them?
How many candle holders you figure you'll get?  Mirabelle
Enough to start my own cathedral.
I'll tell you what I'd want... a Naloni Bucintoro watch. That's right.
Aren't you forgettin' somethin'?
What?
Your husband, the guy you'd be marryin'. Aren't the gifts s'posed to be for both of you?
Oh please. How much enjoyment is he gonna get out of a china bowl, or a crystal flute sitting in a cabinet? So he might as well be not enjoying something that makes me happy.
We have a philosopher among us. Any idea when your big day will come?
I kicked Trent to the curb two months ago, so it probably won't be in the next few weeks. gives Marney a look of disdain.
Serves him right for what he done.
What'd he do?
Made a pass at my mother. I'm still surprised she told me.
Should've set the bastard on fire after somethin' like that.
That's not the answer. Living well's the best revenge.
Oh? Is that what you did after Howard?  Charlene narrows her eyes at Delilah and marches out.
That was a bit below the corset, don't you think?
I'm sorry, Momma. After today, she'll have two weeks to get over it. (to Marney) "Fore I lose another bridesmaid, you mind takin' one o' the programs down to Kelvin?
Sure. Getting a little humid in here. She meanders to the bureau. Ogles the program.
Oh no. Did he have to pose?
Delilah stands next to her bridegroom. He puts up his duk
The bridegroom shadowboxes in front of a mirror. KELVIN WINGFIELD, 30, the body of a flyweight, the ego of a heavyweight. A pencil moustache outlines his upper lip.

You want some o' this? Huh? You want some o' this, Bitch? Cuz I know you can't handle some o' this. The BEST MAN, 20s, trades barbs with three ushers: BUCK, CHUCK and TUCK. They all swig longneck beers.
Kick that chump's ass, Kel. The ushers laugh. A knock on the door.
Beers. Finish 'em. Now. The groomsmen guzzle, toss bottles in the trash. Kelvin fixes his hair in the mirror.
Come in. Marney sashays in.
Delilah wanted me to give you this.
What is it?
The program. Can you get with it?
Bring it here. Let me see it. He motions to his entourage to leave. Marney stomps over. Best Man shuts the door on his way out.
I didn't get a chance to see it. (admires his picture) What do you think of it?
Pretty weak if you ask me.
Weak? There's a word I don't like. Especially from someone so... eye- grabbing.
Please. I feel like Orca coming out of the closet in this thing.
(chuckles) No, I mean it.
You're a good liar. I can tell.

I'm a fighter, Marney. I can't stand for lies and I can't stand for weakness. I pride myself on my strength. (puffs out chest) My agility. (gyrates like a Chippendale dancer) And my ability to... move things. (presses his junk against her) Marney lets out a little squeak. They lock lips, grope at each other like teenagers in a back seat. Kelvin spins Marney around, lifts up her skirt.
These hoop skirts were a great idea. Surprised there even was a war.
Delilah's alone, admiring her engagement ring.
Let go!
Big Baby!
Stop it! I'm telling! Delilah scoots into the
just as Flower Girl slaps the RING BEARER, the seed of Ch but a smidgen taller, in the face.
Hey! Stop it you two! Ring Bearer slaps Flower Girl back, knocking her down. Sh immediately cries.
Shame on you! Don't you ever do that again! Ring Bearer farts with his mouth at Delilah and scrams.
Come back here, you! Don't you ever hit a lady! You hear me?! She stoops to Flower Girl, whose face is puffy pink.
Hey, Sweetie. It's alright. Wanna come with me? Come on, let's go. She helps her up, escorts her into
On the way in, Delilah swipes a hairbrush and a tissue of her bureau. She directs Flower Girl to a small platform that stands before an ornate full-length mirror.
We're gonna fix you up, good as new. (hands tissue) Here you go, Sweetie.  Flower Girl wipes her eyes. Delilah stands behind her, brushing her hair.
Wanna know somethin'?
(sniffling) What? She looks up at Delilah's reflection.

I ain't ever seen a prettier flower girl in my entire life. You know that? 'Deed, it's true. Look at this hair. Bet it drives all the boys wild. They're just not sure why yet. Wait until it gets long. You'll have to beat 'em off with a curlin' iron. There. All better. Now, wanna come see me get married?
The Guests chat boisterously on rows of folding chairs, separated by an aisle of manicured grass. A brass QUINTET occupies the final row.
Try not to screw it up this time.
Blow it out your arse.
The MINISTER, 50s, emerges in a gray suit and red bow tie Smiles at the large gathering. Kelvin appears, looking a bit disheveled, buttons his jac The Quintet plays PRELUDE MUSIC.
How's it going?
Good. Thank you for asking. Feeling a bit nervous?
No, actually. I'm quite relaxed.

Splendid. The PROCESSION begins. Buck escorts Mirabelle and KELVIN'S MOM, 50s, a museum o Silicone and collagen, to their seats in the front row. Best Man follows, arm in arm with the Maid of Honor, Char He waves like he's just arrived on Oscar night. Chuck and Tuck strut down the aisle.
You and Jezebel thinking of getting married?
Her name's Jesselyn, jackass.

Jesselyn Jackass. I like it. The Bridesmaids, including a rumpled Marney, parade in pa Behind them, the Ring Bearer, looking sweaty and confused And then, the Flower Girl. She freckles the aisle with magnolia petals. Ring Bearer turns and gives her a dirty look. She proudly produces her tongue for him. A pregnant pause. Anticipation builds amongst the Guests. The Quintet strikes up Mendelssohn's WEDDING MARCH. Delilah appears with her father, SAMUEL, 50s, silver hair and a downward smile, a keeper of many secrets. The bride carries a bouquet of pink magnolias. They proceed down the aisle. Flashbulbs and smiles light the tent. Kelvin steals a look at Marney, who blushes.
(whispers) Think they did it?
Course they did, look at her. She's as pink as a baboon's ass. The Minister turns to the Best Man, shocked.
Sorry, Your Honor. Kelvin sneers at Mirabelle and Charlene, both looking blo and uncomfortable as they fan themselves. Delilah and Samuel arrive at the altar.
Who gives this woman in marriage?
I do. Samuel kisses Delilah's cheek, puts her hand in Kelvin's. He takes a seat next to Mirabelle.

Dearly Beloved, we are gathered together here in the sight of God to join together this Man and this Woman in holy Matrimony. If any man- or woman- can show just cause, why they may not lawfully be joined together, let him- or her- now speak or forever hold their peace. Marney has a COUGHING fit. A murmur ripples through the crowd. Delilah scowls at her.
Is she gagging on something?
But he's standing all the way over here.
Shut up. Kelvin and Delilah face each other.

Kelvin, wilt thou have this woman as thy wedded wife, to live together after God's ordinance in the holy estate of Matrimony? Wilt thou love her, comfort her, honor, and keep her in sickness and in health; and, forsaking all others, keep thee only unto her, so long as ye both shall live?
I... been doing some thinking. GASPS from the crowd nearly bring down the tent.
Woops.
What?  10.
Look... Delilah's eyes bug as Kelvin searches for the right words
I'm a fighter, Delilah. I can't stand for lies and I can't stand for weakness. I pride myself on --
What in God's name are you talkin' about?
I think I got a few more good rounds in me. And I just don't think I'm ready to hang up my belt. Capeesh?

I'll show you capeesh. She swings at him with her left. Kelvin slips her punch. A right from Delilah. He slips it again. She winds up and delivers a roundhouse left. Kelvin slips her punch for a third time, only this time, Delilah trips her train and collapses. She CLONKS her head on the stage
My God! Is she alright?! Mirabelle faints. Delilah's out like a light. The Ministe stoops down to assist. He peers up at Kelvin but he's gon The bridegroom leaves with his entourage.
Another TKO from the K-man. The Guests stand with their mouths agape. Some shout: "Wh are you going?" And "You forgot your bride." Children Boo
Mirabelle holds smelling salts under Delilah's nose.
(opens her eyes) Yeckh, what is that? Get that thing away from me.

A little gratitude would be nice. I've never done this before.  11. Delilah sits up. Nearly everyone has left. It begins to sink in: The Wedding That Never was. Charlene and Marney sit in the first row looking desponde Samuel approaches Delilah, kneels down next to her.
Are you alright, Honeybee? Let me help you up.
Leave her be! She needs to do it herself. Samuel backs off.
(slowly stands) What happened?
You mean you don't remember? He left you. The one wearing the tuxedo.
Thanks, Momma. That helps.
I think Delilah could do without the snide remarks right now.
What do you know about it? Do you know what went into putting on this wedding day?!
I think I do. I paid for it.
That's just marvelous. And what did I invest? Nothing at all, right?! Only the fancy wedding invitations, and the registry, and that Godforsaken rehearsal dinner --
I just think --
Those God-awful programs, and the fittings, and the million alterations on those bloody hoop skirts, and the guest list, and the thank you cards --
Don't you think --  12.

And the photographer, and the videographer, and the caterer, and the minister, and the florist, and the band, and that fat slob chauffeur brother of yours, AND a five thousand dollar cake that nobody ate!
Yes, but, this wasn't Delilah's fault. Mirabelle huffs and storms off. Samuel watches her leave. He takes a seat, dizzy and disconcerted. Delilah turns to her sister and Marney.
This isn't really happenin', right?
I'm sorry, Honey. A hint of a smile appears on Charlene's face. She looks away, trying to hide it.
Is somethin' funny?
No.
Then why are you smilin'?
Nothing. It's nothing.
I bet I look pretty funny, huh? "When Beauty Queen Weddings Go Wrong." Right? Fox is gonna be all over my ass now. Real funny, Charlene. Charlene can't hold it any longer. She bursts out laughin
I'm sorry, Delilah. (scampers away)
Some family. Samuel gives her a pained look. Delilah sits next to Marn  13.
This was so humiliatin'. There ain't no comin' back from somethin' like this.
You will, Sweetie. Might not feel like it now, but... you'll see. The sun will come up tomorrow, right? Isn't that what the 1i'l orphan girl says?
I just wanna beat him senseless.
You could do that. But that'll just get you thrown in jail for assault "n battery. It's not worth it.
How could he do that to me?

Honey, men like Kelvin are a dime a baker's dozen. Crying over somebody like that, well... that's just foolish if you ask me. You can do better. Delilah spies the wedding cake in the corner of the tent.
I swear to you... Delilah charges at the cake like a belle out of hell. She flails at it, stirring up a whirlwind of icing.

(mocking Kelvin) You been doin' some thinkin', huh?! You couldn't think up a brain fart! I'll give you somethin' to think about ! Strawberry mousse splatters all over her hoop skirt as sh punches away. Samuel buries his head in his hands. Delilah snatches the figurine of Kelvin atop the cake and flings it into the trees.

Smallest pecker I've ever seen! Marney raises her eyebrows, confused by the comment. Deli looks down at herself, thoroughly covered in cake. Perhap a moment of clarity. Then, shamelessly, she licks herself  14. Mirabelle and Charlene pop back into the tent. They get a eyeful of Delilah going to town on the cake. Her indulgen verges on pornography.
(aghast) Oh my word.
(salivating) Oh my word.

Remnants of a wedding cake and dress decorate the floor. Delilah lies dormant on her bed, face first into her pill The ALARM CLOCK goes off: the sound of a Boxing Fight Bel Delilah reaches her hand out and shuts it off.
Delilah, still in bed. One-gallon buckets of ice cream ha been hollowed out. They sit sadly on the floor by the bed Her phone rings, Delilah reaches for it.
Hello.
Delilah? It's me, Cassandra. How're you holding up?
I'm fine. An empty pint of ice cream falls off the end of the bed. silver spoon rattles on the floor.
Listen... I'm not gonna be able to make it to that picnic on Sunday...
But we've been plannin' that for a month.
I know, but... something just came up, and uhh... I'm sorry, but I can't.
Oh. What came up?  15.
Umm... I'm just not comfortable talking about it.
Okay. Bye... (hangs up)

Delilah, still in bed. Pizza boxes have joined the empty ice cream containers on the floor. One box, half-eaten, sits squarely on Delilah's wedding dress. Her alarm clock goes off. Delilah flings it across the ro She returns her face to the pillow and shuts her eyes. Slowly, her eyes open again. They focus ona
of Kelvin boxing in the ring. Delilah picks it up and studies it. An epiphany.
Assault 'n battery, my hot ass. From under her bed, she pulls out the Yellow Pages.
Delilah saunters in. Her hair a tangled, greasy mess. Mirabelle and Charlene eat breakfast at the table.
Mornin'. How y'all doin'?
We're okay. How are you?
(strolls to counter) I feel rejuvenated. 'Deed, I do. There's a renaissance goin' on in my pajamas as we speak.
Okaaay. She turns to her mother like Delilah might be nuts.
Delilah, I didn't raise you to talk like that.  Delilah pours herself a glass of orange juice.

You know somethin', Momma? You are ab-so-lute-ly right. You taught me to speak proper, act like a lady, drown all my sorrows in iced tea, and take action when the need calls for it. And you know what? That's exactly what I'm gonna do.
What are you talking about, for heaven's sake?
(downs her juice) Y'all are lookin' at the first female boxer in all the MacIntosh family. Mirabelle EXPLODES with laughter. Charlene looks at her mother terrified.
That's right. You laugh. But I'm tellin' you right now... I'm gonna box my way up the ranks and beat the bejesus outta his skinny-little ass. Give 'im a taste of humiliation he won't soon forget.
You're saying you're gonna box Kelvin.
That's exactly what I'm sayin', 0 Sister O' Mine.
That's insane. He'd kill you.
That's where you're wrong, my sweet 1i'l dumplin'. Hell hath no fury like a beauty queen scorned. You just remember that.
Delilah parks her pink 1970 Mini Cooper in the lot. wears a fuchsia sweat suit and matching makeup.

The THUMPING of heavy bags, the STACCATO hammering of spe bags. A few weight benches sit in a far corner.  17. In an 18' x 18' ring, female boxer SLICE, 30s and lean wi reddish hair, spars with an OPPONENT. Ringside is TANDY BURROWS. She's 30, buff with a harsh Bo accent, her glinty eyes have seen more than their share.
Christ, Slice, keep your chin down! Delilah flits in carrying her fuchsia purse. Unsure where to go, she approaches Tandy.
Excuse me. Where do I --
Can't you fuckin' see I'm busy?
Oh, I'm... sorry.

Go pahk your ass ova there. Delilah ambles to the opposite side of the ring. Many of the GYM-GOERS give her the once-over. TWO of them snigger as they toss a medicine ball back and forth. In the ring, Slice is throttled by two left hooks. Delila looks on as Slice retaliates, hammering her Opponent.
Take it easy, you're losing your shit! Slice doesn't seem to hear, or care. Throws a rabbit punc
Time! She enters the ring livid, stomps straight over to Slice.
What did I tell you about keeping your cool?
I wasn't pissed off.

Bull-shit. You lost it. I already told you. If you get mad, you get crazy, and if you get crazy, you're gonna end up in a hospital. I'm not having that here. This ain't about emotion. It's about heart. You better learn the difference.
One more hard look through Slice and Tandy exits the ring A look of concern sweeps over Delilah's face.
If you're looking for the mall, you head straight down Fahm, then --
I'm aware where the mall is, thank you.
Whaddya want, then?
Is this your gym?
Better fuckin' believe it.
My name's Delilah MacIntosh. It's nice to meet you. She puts out her hand, comes up empty.
You running for office?
Nope. I'm campaignin' to be a boxer.
Good God No.
On the walls, a tribute to the female boxer. Tandy sits with her feet up behind a desk, squeezing a tennis ball i each hand. Delilah fills out an application on a clipboar
I never got your name.
Tandy. So what brings a girl like you to boxing?
Well... I'm a graduate of Norton Beauty College. I've got my manicurist license, as well as my cosmetology license. (MORE )
I won the Miss Georgia beauty pageant two years ago. And um, this year, I'm the Magnolia Princess.
So... what brings a girl like you to boxing?

Oh. I wanted to change career paths. Uh huh. I mean, beauty's only skin deep, right? That's what they always say. 'N who knows, maybe they're right. Workin' in an office is just not my thing. I'd die if I had to sit in a cube all day, wouldn't you? Tandy looks dizzy, rubs the confusion from her eyes.
You married? Delilah covers her engagement ring.
No. Still single.
Well, Delilah, I gotta warn you. Boxing's a far cry from doing the friggin' catwalk. Ya follow me? It can get pretty brutal out there.
Dangit! An eyelash got in my eye. Just a sec. Slyly, she slips off her engagement ring, drops it into h pocketbook, and takes out her compact.
Lately, my eyelashes seem to have a mind o' their own. I dunno what's goin' on with them.
Yeah, I can see how that might be hard. She smirks at Delilah as she fishes for an eyelash.  20.
(closes her compact) Miss Tandy. I don't wanna inconvenience you, truly I don't. But I do know that if I'm gonna box, I'm sure as hellfire gonna need someone to train me.
Amen to that.
So if it's not too much trouble... you think you might be up for it?
Why me?
Why you?
Yeah, why'd you pick me?
Well um... I heard you were the best, so... why would I settle for somethin' less? Tandy raises an eyebrow.
Is my hair a mess? I'm sorry. It was real windy on the way in here.

Delilah, your resume's pretty damn impressive, I'll give you that. But I don't see how beauty pageants and a manicure license qualify you as a boxer. Boxing's about discipline. Not how pretty you look. I think you should stick with what you're good at. You're just not cut out for something like this.

You know what? That's where you're wrong. You have any idea what it takes to win a beauty pageant? Do you? A million miles on the treadmill, all the food you can't eat, can't drink, can't smoke, don't smile too much or you might get laugh lines, takin' vitamins every day, (MORE )

minerals, herbs, flaxseed, grapeseed, whatever-seed, and still try to find a way to sleep eight hours a night when all you can think about is that chocolate fudge cake sittin' in the fridge. Don't let the mascara and eyeliner fool you, Miss Tandy. I'm all about discipline. Now are you gonna train me or what? Tandy stares at Delilah in silence. She pulls out a notep and pen, scribbles.
There's things you're gonna need. You can pick 'em up at Jesse's around the corner. Be here tomorrow at eight. And when you get here, could you be a little less... pink?
Delilah pushes a shopping cart loaded with neon sweats an shirts. She swipes a salmon sweatshirt off a shelf.
Nope. Too pink. A SALESPERSON, 20s, with a bump on his nose, approaches.
How might I help you, ma'am?
Oh, hi. I need a big bag.
A what?
A big bag. You know, for boxin'.
Oh, you mean a heavy bag.
That's right.
Right. Follow me. (rolls eyes)  22. Delilah follows him down an aisle.
I'm gonna be a boxer. Isn't it great?
Um, yeah. Good for you. He stops in front of a row of black and brown heavy bags.
We have these here. They're well- manufactured and --
Do you have anythin' happier?
Happier.
Yeah. I mean, look at these. They're all so dull-lookin'. (points to brown one) This one looks like King Kong had an accident. Who wants to see that?
Miss, I hope you don't mind my asking, but, why boxing? I mean, look at you. You're a knockout.
Ha!
Guess I stepped into that one. Look, I'm sorry, but I'm afraid we don't have any happier-looking heavy bags.
That's too bad.
Can I interest you in a slam, ma'am?
What?! She PUNCHES him in the nose.  23.
Ow! He keels over, blood trickles from his nose.
How could you say a thing like that to me?
You heard me wrong. I said a SlamMan.
Oh. Huh?
Delilah stands face to face with a SLAMMAN, a freestandin heavy bag shaped like the head and torso of a man. Bumpy holds a pink t-shirt to his nose. Delilah gives Sla the evil eye.
I'll take ‘im.
Delilah strides in wearing yellow sweats. She carries an oversized gym bag.
Delilah sidles past THREE SWEATY WOMEN on their way out.
No breakfast, and she comes in looking like a banana split.
Heh. Watch out.

I got Cool Whip at home. Delilah crams her gym bag into a locker. She turns to lea and on the wall she notices a SIGN: People Steal So Use Your Head. Delilah frowns, turns the dial on the combination lock. S pulls out her gym bag, removes her pocketbook from inside Takes out her engagement ring. She studies it, debates whether to pocket it. Tosses the ring into the locker.  24.
Delilah jumps rope. Tandy supervises. The rope gets tangled up in her feet and she tumbles.
Darnit!
Rope's too long for ya. Stand on it with both feet and pull up. Delilah steps on the rope, the ends touch her shoulders.
Let me see it. She takes the rope and shortens it.
Now try. Delilah skips. Better this time.
Why aren't we boxin'?
You ain't in no fuckin' shape to box.
What? I'm skinny.
Don't talk, Goldilocks. Just jump.
Delilah scampers around the track, breathing heavily. Tan sips a Coke as she strolls along the grassy center.
You know. I just have to say. That is pretty tacky. You sippin' a soda while I sweat my mammaries off.
I'm gonna go grab some rum from my trunk. Be right back. Delilah growls. Tandy strides away.
Tandy glides toward the track. Delilah's doubled over, searching for air.  25.
Looks like we got quite a fuckin' ways to go, don't we. Why were you running so fast? Your pantalets on fire? You gotta pace yourself. Delilah stands upright. Dark mascara streams down her che
Fuckin' fright night.
Tandy idles in her Mustang. She revs the motor. Delilah trudges toward her, her cheeks still streaked. TwO BELLES look on from a parked Lexus.
They slurp milk shakes.
You hear about what happened to her?
Yup. It's a shame.
Sure is.
Never thought she'd go Goth though.
Delilah drags in behind Tandy and heads for the locker ro
Where ya going, Goldilocks?
Home.

We're not done yet. Get your ass over here. I want ya to meet some o' the regulars. Tandy leads Delilah over to HANK, 20s, Korean heavyweight perfect gentleman but in no danger of making the cover of GQ; and ROMEO, 20s, African-American, with flamboyant tru Hank fields Romeo's punches with focus mitts.
Guys, this here's Delilah.  26. Slice sneers at Delilah as she destroys the heavy bag.
You takin' in strays from the Junior League?
I'm training Goldilocks here to box.
Yeah, and I'm training my dog to shit in the toilet.
So nice to meet you.
Don't let her bother you. I'm Hank. He offers a gloved hand to Delilah, and in the process mi a punch from Romeo to the kisser. It barely registers.
It's a pleasure. Didn't that hurt?
It's no problem. He misses all the time.
Oh hush. My name's Romeo. I could never wear that color yellow, but it looks divine on you.
Thank you so much. I like your shorts. Where'd you find that color? I didn't see any like it at Jesse's.
Oh, I made these myself. I'd be happy to make you a --

(claps) Alright, ladies. This ain't a friggin' fashion show. I gotta teach Delilah here some basics. C'mere. Slice bares her teeth at Delilah, hits the bag with a flu of punches. Delilah blanches and scurries over to Tandy.
Stand in front o' the mirror so you can see what you're doing. Put your feet like this. (MORE )
(demonstrates) You're a rightie, so lead with your left. Feet shoulder-width apart. Put your fists up. Delilah crouches like she's got a load in her pants.
Don't bend so far. You're not in the bathroom. We're gonna start off slow. Just jab with your left, (jabs) punching straight out from your chin. Delilah clenches her fists and punches wildly.
Like that?
Don't clench your fist. Keep your fingers relaxed. (jabs in slow-motion) Straight from the chin. Then squeeze right before ya reach your target. Delilah jabs again. A little better.
Okay. Now this time, turn your fist a little when you punch. (shows her) Like that. So ya go from holding your fist vertical to horizontal.
(jabs again) Better?
Just keep doing it. Watch yourself in the mirror. I'm sure you can manage that. Slice stalks over to Tandy as Delilah jabs away.
Why you humoring the poor girl?
There's something there. It's just buried under a pile o' grits.  28.
Vacant. Delilah treks in alone. She opens her locker and pulls out her gym bag. No sign of an engagement ring. A little grin.

Delilah slogs in, flicks on the light. Sticking out like sore thumb in the center of the room is SlamMan. She drops her gym bag on the floor, notices a STICKY NOTE SlamMan's forehead: "We Need To Talk."
Delilah, in a sea foam green sweatsuit with matching sweatband, practices her jab in front of the mirror. No makeup today. Romeo passes on his way to the ring.
Looking good there.
Thanks! Tandy emerges from her office, frowns at Delilah's form.
Keep your chin tucked, Goldilocks. This ain't no beauty pageant. Snap it out and pull it back. She stands next to Delilah in the mirror, demonstrates.
Snap it out. Pull it back. Fast. Let your punch hang and you'll fuckin' get pummeled. Delilah picks up the pace.
You're gonna throw this punch the most, so ya sure as shit better make it count. Now show me your right. Delilah swings a roundhouse right.
What are ya, breaking up a bar fight? Throw the punch straight. That's why they call it a straight right. (demonstrates) This time, the power's not coming from your arm.  29.
It's not?
Nope. It's coming from your torso, (places her hands on Delilah's torso) and from your right foot when ya pivot. Delilah tries a few straight rights.
Put your back into it. Delilah adds more oomph.
Good. Explode 'n pull back. Think you're ready for the heavy bag?

That bastard.

Hank holds the heavy bag as Delilah, in electric blue swe slugs away. Tandy looks on. Delilah's getting better, mix in some left hooks and uppercuts with her jabs.

and pulls

Too young.

I dunno. Saturday... I think I might have something going on.
That makes one of us.
What's the charity?  45.
Southern Belles With Fat Lips... Foundation.

I won't stand for this. It's bad enough we spent thousands of dollars on her wedding and have nothing to show for it. But now she's got this cockamamie idea in her head that's gonna threaten her only asset which is her looks. I won't stand for it. You have to talk to her.
